program means a Parenting after Separation Program operated by the Family Justice Services Division of the Ministry of Attorney General;
program administrator means a person employed by the minister to review exemption requests made under subrule (6).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of this rule is to promote the best interests of children by providing a program to persons in dispute over issues respecting children.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: This rule applies in designated registries
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to the exceptions set out in subrule (4), this rule applies to the following applications if the application is filed in a designated registry or the court file for the proceeding is transferred under rule 19 to a designated registry:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact with a child;
for child support;
to change, suspend or terminate an order for anything listed in paragraph (a) or (b);
to set aside or replace a filed agreement for anything listed in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Parties in some cases need not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: None of the parties need attend a program if one of the parties files a parenting after separation exemption request in Form 31 and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a consent order is filed that resolves all issues involving children,
a director under the Child, Family and Community Services Act is a party,

the application is for child support only and a party has assigned child support rights to the government under the Employment and Assistance Act or the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act,
the application is made under the Interjurisdictional Support Orders Act, or
one or both of the parties is seeking an order for return of a child under the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction signed at The Hague on October 25, 1980.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A party who has already attended
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, a party need not attend a program if that party files a parenting after separation exemption request in Form 31 stating that the party has attended and completed a program in the 24 months immediately preceding the date of filing the request.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A party who is unable to attend the program
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A program administrator may exempt a party from attending a program if the party provides to the program administrator a parenting after separation exemption request in Form 31 that states one of the following reasons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party is not fluent in a language in which a program is offered;
the party resides in a community where a program is not offered and the party has no electronic access to a program;
the party is incapable of attending due to a serious medical condition.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may grant exemption or deferral
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On application a judge may dispense with or defer the application of this rule to one or more parties if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party has applied for an order under Part 9 of the Family Law Act, or
the judge is satisfied that urgent and exceptional circumstances exist requiring a judge to hear the matter at the earliest opportunity.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: One party must attend program before date set
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (4), (5), (6) and (7), a date for a first court appearance will not be set until either the applicant or respondent files a Certificate of Attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Both parties must attend program before court appearance
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If this rule applies, but subject to subrules (4), (5), (6) and (7), both the applicant and respondent must attend a program and must file a Certificate of Attendance on or before the date of the first court appearance.
In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: electronic document means a document that has been transmitted for filing electronically;
electronic services agreement means an agreement referred to in subrule (3);
registered user means a person who has entered into an electronic services agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: This rule applies in event of conflict
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In the event of a conflict between this rule and another rule, this rule applies.
A person wishing to file documents in a registry under this rule must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enter into an agreement with the Court Services Branch of the Ministry of Attorney General respecting the terms and conditions under which those filings may be made, and
submit documents for filing in accordance with that agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A registered user may electronically transmit a document to a registry for filing if the document is not one referred to in subrule (5).
The following documents may not be transmitted for filing electronically:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a summons to a default hearing in Form 7A;
a summons to a committal hearing in Form 7B;
a certificate of service in Form 14;
an application to recognize an extraprovincial order for guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact in Form 22;
a request for court enforcement under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act in Form 23.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An affidavit or other signed document that is being filed for evidentiary purposes, if submitted for filing electronically, must clearly identify the signatory and must be accompanied by a statement, in Form 33, of the lawyer acting for the person on whose behalf the document is submitted for filing or, if that person is unrepresented, by a statement of that person, in Form 33, indicating that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the original paper version of the document appears to bear an original signature of the person identified as the signatory and the person making the Form 33 statement has no reason to believe that the signature placed on the document is not the signature of the identified signatory, and

the version of the document that is being submitted for filing electronically appears to be a true copy of the original paper version of the document and the person making the Form 33 statement has no reason to believe that it is not a true copy of the original paper version.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who, under subrule (6), submits a document for filing electronically under these rules must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: keep the original paper version of the document until the earliest of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date on which the proceeding, including any appeals, is finally disposed of,
the date on which the appeal period for the proceeding has expired if no notice of appeal respecting the proceeding has been filed within that period, and
the date on which a judge orders that the original paper version be filed, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a request is made under paragraph (a) (iii), file the original paper version promptly after that request is made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document in paper form is filed, a clerk of the registry in which the document was filed may convert the document into electronic form and, in that event, the clerk must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: store the conversion in a computer or in another electronic system that the clerk considers appropriate, and
retain the paper form of the document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who submits a document referred to in subrule (6) for filing electronically must, on request, make the original paper version of that document available for inspection by other parties or their lawyers and by the court.

A person who is entitled to inspect a document under subrule (9) may, if that inspection is denied, apply by notice of motion to a judge under rule 12 for an order that the original paper version of the document be filed.
Rule 13 continues to apply to affidavits filed under this rule, but, in the event of a conflict between this rule and rule 13 in respect of those affidavits, this rule prevails.

For the purposes of these rules other than subrule (6) of this rule, a document is deemed to have been originally signed if it has been electronically authenticated in the manner contemplated by the applicable electronic services agreement.
If a document that has been transmitted for filing electronically is accepted for filing by a clerk, the document is deemed to have been filed as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is received by the registry at or before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or a holiday, the document is deemed to be filed on the day of receipt;
if the document is received by the registry on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be filed on the next day that is not a Saturday or a holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a document that has been transmitted for filing electronically is accepted for filing by a clerk, the clerk must affix an electronic version of the registry stamp to the document and, after that, must provide a copy of the stamped electronic document, in the manner contemplated by the electronic services agreement, to the person who transmitted the document for filing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Public access to documents filed electronically
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a document has been filed under this rule, a person who is otherwise entitled to view and obtain a copy of the document may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain from the registry a paper copy of the document,

if a public access computer terminal is available in the registry, view the document on that terminal or, if the document is not available for viewing on that terminal, view on that terminal the information about the document or its contents, if any, that is available on that terminal, or
if the person is a registered user, access the document in accordance with the terms of the electronic services agreement entered into by that person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document that may or must be served on a person may, if it is an electronic document, be served on the person in a manner contemplated by rule 9 or as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person has provided an e-mail address for service, by e-mailing it to that person's e-mail address for service;
if the lawyer for the person has provided an e-mail address for service, by e-mailing it to that lawyer's e-mail address for service;
if paragraph (a) or (b) applies and, under these rules, multiple copies of the document are to be served, the serving party need serve only a single electronic copy of the document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If document does not reach a person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Even though a document has been served in accordance with subrule (16), a person may show, on an application to set aside the consequences of default, on an application for an extension of time or on an application in support of a request for an adjournment, that the document

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not come to the person's notice,
did come to the person's notice later than when it was served or effectively served, or
was incomplete or illegible.

bcl:form.bcl:centertext: In the Provincial Court of British Columbia
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: (Set out the street address of the address for service. One or both of a fax number and an e-mail address may be given as additional addresses for service.)

bcl:lefttext.in:strong:
IMPORTANT NOTES TO RESPONDENT:
If this application contains a claim for support, you are required to file financial information with your reply. If you do not, the court may attribute income to you and set the amount of support to be paid. The applicant has estimated your gross annual income as set out in item
If you fail to file a reply within 30 days after being served with this application, you will not receive notice of any part of the proceeding and the court may make an order against you.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: Are there any court orders or written agreements between the parties concerning separation, guardianship, parenting arrangements, contact with a child or support?

oasis:entry.oasis:line: [ ] I am attaching copies of all orders
[ ] I am attaching copies of all written agreements

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: The respondent's relationship to the child(ren) is .........................................................
3 — Support (Complete if you are asking for child or spousal support.)
I am asking for: (Complete only if you are asking for child support.)
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: [ ] support in the amount set out in the Child Support Guidelines for ..........[number]......... children
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: I am asking for: (Complete only if you are asking for retroactive child support or retroactive spousal support.)
You must complete Form 4, following the instructions on that form, if:
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: • there is a claim for spousal support,
• there is a claim for child support and one or more of the following applies:
bcl:form.bcl:indent2: • you are the person being asked to pay;
• the claim is for an amount other than the amount set out in the tables of the Child Support Guidelines, including a claim under section 8, 9 or 10 of the Child Support Guidelines;
• there is a claim under section 7 [special or extraordinary expenses] of the Child Support Guidelines;
• one or more of the children for whom support is claimed is 19 years of age or older;
• the person who is being asked to pay is a stepparent, or a guardian who is not a parent, of one or more of the children for whom support is claimed.
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: You may also provide this financial information before receiving the respondent's reply, in order to avoid delay, if you believe that the income of a respondent from whom child support is claimed is over $150 000 per year or that the respondent will claim undue hardship, special or extraordinary expenses or make a counterclaim for support.
4 — Protection Orders (Complete if you are asking for a protection order.)

bcl:centertext.in:em: If the applicant in this proceeding is represented by a lawyer, the lawyer must complete the following certificate.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: I, ....................................., lawyer for .....................[name of party].............. certify that, in accordance with section 8 (2) of the Family Law Act, I have
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: (a) discussed with the party the advisability of using various types of family dispute resolution to resolve the matter, and
(b) informed the party of the facilities and other resources, known to me, that may be available to assist in resolving the dispute.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: APPLICATION RESPECTING EXISTING ORDERS OR AGREEMENTS

bcl:form.bcl:centertext: In the Provincial Court of British Columbia
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: (Set out the street address of the address for service. One or both of a fax number and an e-mail address may be given as additional addresses for service.)

oasis:entry.oasis:line: [ ] Minister under the Employment and Assistance Act or the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act

bcl:lefttext.in:strong:
IMPORTANT NOTE:
If this claim involves an order for support, you may be required to file financial information. If you do not, the court may attribute income to you and set the amount of support to be paid.

IMPORTANT NOTE TO RESPONDENT: If you fail to file a reply within 30 days after being served with this application, you will not receive notice of any part of the proceeding and the court may make an order against you.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: [ ] I ask that the attached order dated ......[mmm/dd/yyyy]...... be changed to the following:....................
[ ] I ask that the attached order dated ......[mmm/dd/yyyy]...... be suspended.
[ ] I ask that the attached order dated ......[mmm/dd/yyyy]...... be terminated.
[ ] I ask that arrears of support be reduced or cancelled as follows: ...........................................................
[ ] I ask that the attached agreement dated ......[mmm/dd/yyyy]...... be set aside in whole or in part.
[ ] I ask that the attached agreement dated ......[mmm/dd/yyyy]...... be replaced.
[ ] I ask for an order under section 19 (2) of the Interjurisdictional Support Orders Act to set aside the registration of a foreign order under that Act.
[ ] I ask for an order under section 35 of the Interjurisdictional Support Orders Act to vary a support order registered in British Columbia.

bcl:centertext.in:em: If the applicant in this proceeding is represented by a lawyer, the lawyer must complete the following certificate.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: I, ....................................., lawyer for .....................[name of party].............. certify that, in accordance with section 8 (2) of the Family Law Act, I have
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: (a) discussed with the party the advisability of using various types of family dispute resolution to resolve the matter, and
(b) informed the party of the facilities and other resources, known to me, that may be available to assist in resolving the dispute.

bcl:form.bcl:centertext: In the Provincial Court of British Columbia
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: (Set out the street address of the address for service. One or both of a fax number and an e-mail address may be given as additional addresses for service.)

bcl:lefttext.in:strong:
IMPORTANT NOTE TO APPLICANT:
If the respondent's reply includes a claim for support, you, the original applicant, are required to file financial information. If you do not, the court may attribute income to you and set the amount of support to be paid. The respondent has estimated your gross annual income as set out in item 2 below.

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: I agree with the request(s) of the applicant for:
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: [ ] a change in or suspension or termination of an earlier order dated .....[mmm/dd/yyyy].......
[ ] an order to set aside or replace an agreement dated .....[mmm/dd/yyyy].......
[ ] an order that arrears of support be reduced or cancelled
bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: I disagree with the request(s) of the applicant for:

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: TAKE NOTICE THAT any police officer, including any R.C.M.P. officer having jurisdiction in the province of British Columbia, having reasonable and probable grounds to believe that the person against whom this order is made has contravened a term of this order may take action to enforce the order, whether or not there is proof that the order has been served on the person and, if necessary, may use reasonable force. Enforcement action may include arresting the person against whom this order is made without warrant in accordance with section 495 of the Criminal Code.
AND TAKE NOTICE THAT if no expiry date is ordered in relation to this order, this order expires one year after the date it is made.

(In these cases the requirement does not apply to either the applicant or the respondent.)

oasis:entry.oasis:line: applying for an order for guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact with a child or a child support order in the Abbotsford, Campbell River, Chilliwack, Courtenay, Kamloops, Kelowna, Nanaimo, New Westminster, North Vancouver, Penticton, Port Coquitlam, Prince George, Richmond, Surrey, Vancouver (Robson Square), Vernon or Victoria registry of the Provincial Court, or
applying to change, suspend or terminate an existing order for guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact with a child or a child support order in these courts,

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: the court requires you to attend a Parenting after Separation (PAS) session before you appear in court.
For Respondents. If you are named as the other party (respondent):

oasis:entry.oasis:line: in an application in the Abbotsford, Campbell River, Chilliwack, Courtenay, Kamloops, Kelowna, Nanaimo, New Westminster, North Vancouver, Penticton, Port Coquitlam, Prince George, Richmond, Surrey, Vancouver (Robson Square), Vernon or Victoria registry of the Provincial Court, and
you wish to appear in court to respond to this application,

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: the court requires you to attend a Parenting after Separation (PAS) session before you appear in court.
Also, check the information in the package of court documents you receive to see what other steps you have to take if you wish to respond to an application.
bcl:form.bcl:indent1: Register for a PAS session. The PAS brochure in this package tells you who to contact for PAS sessions in your area. Attend the session and receive a Certificate of Attendance. File the Certificate of Attendance at the court registry.

bcl:lefttext.in:strong: When this requirement may not apply:

bcl:form.bcl:lefttext: In some situations you may not be required to attend a PAS session (be exempt). Look at the Exemption Form now to see if you are exempt. Sometimes one or both parties are automatically exempt. These situations are listed on the front page of the form. The reasons listed on the back page of the form apply only if you receive permission from the PAS Program Administrator to be exempt from attending.

If your situation is urgent, for example: you are concerned about your safety or the safety of your children, be sure to tell staff at the Provincial Court Registry or the Family Justice Centre or your lawyer. Other exemptions might apply to you.

A first court appearance cannot be set until one of the parties (applicant or respondent) files a Certificate of Attendance or shows that he or she did not have to attend. Both parties must file a certificate before they appear in court or show that they are exempt.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Appendix, the definitions in rule 5.01 (1) apply.
In this Appendix:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: early resolution requirements means the requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements];
these rules means the Provincial Court (Family) Rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Citation
bcl:section.bcl:text: This Appendix may be cited as the "Early Resolution and Case Management Model" and is included within any reference to the "Provincial Court (Family) Rules".

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Designation of early resolution and case management model registry
bcl:section.bcl:text: This Early Resolution and Case Management Model applies in the Victoria registry, which is designated as an early resolution and case management model registry.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose
bcl:section.bcl:text: The purpose of the Early Resolution and Case Management Model is to encourage parties to resolve their cases by agreement or to help them obtain a just and timely decision in a way that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: takes into account the impact that the conduct of a case may have on a child and family,
minimizes conflict,
promotes cooperation between the parties, and
provides processes for resolution that are efficient and consistent with the complexity of the cases to be resolved.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Early resolution requirements
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before filing an application about a family law matter under Part 3 [Application about Family Law Matters], a person seeking resolution of a family law matter in an early resolution and case management registry must, unless otherwise provided in this Early Resolution and Case Management Model,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice to resolve in Form A [Notice to Resolve a Family Law Matter] of Appendix C,
provide a copy of the notice to resolve to the other person,
attend a needs assessment under section 10 [participating in needs assessment],
complete a parenting education program under section 12 [completing parenting education program], and
participate in at least one consensual dispute resolution session under section 13 [participating in consensual dispute resolution].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exception to early resolution requirements
bcl:section.bcl:text: The early resolution requirements described in section 5 are not required if a person is only applying for one or more orders that are to be made under Part 5 [Case Management Orders] or 6 [Applying for Other Orders].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection orders and orders about priority parenting matters take priority
bcl:section.bcl:text: For certainty, if a party applies for an order about

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a protection order under Part 9 [Protection from Family Violence] of the Family Law Act, or
a priority parenting matter

bcl:section.bcl:text: in addition to an order about a family law matter, the party may apply for the order about the protection order or the priority parenting matter before complying with the early resolution requirements under this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may waive or vary requirements

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, rule 20 (2) [judge may waive or vary rules] of these rules applies to this Early Resolution and Case Management Model.
A party may make an application to waive or vary the early resolution requirements in accordance with Part 5 [Case Management Orders] of this Early Resolution and Case Management Model.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Intention to proceed in certain cases after one year

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The parties must meet the requirements of subsection (2) if no application about a family law matter has been filed and more than one year has passed since the latest date on which one of the parties took any of the following steps in the case:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filed a notice to resolve a family law matter in Form A [Notice to Resolve a Family Law Matter] of Appendix C;
participated in a needs assessment;
completed a parenting education program;
participated in a consensual dispute resolution session.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before the parties described in subsection (1) may proceed under this Early Resolution and Case Management Model,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party must file a notice of intention to proceed in Form B [Notice of Intention to Proceed] of Appendix C and provide a copy of the notice to the other party, and
the parties must participate in a new needs assessment.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Participating in needs assessment
bcl:section.bcl:text: Each party must participate in a needs assessment conducted by a needs assessor for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assistance with identifying legal and non-legal needs;
information about resolving issues, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: how to resolve family law matters and other issues out of court, and
how to apply for a court order;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provision of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a referral to an appropriate parenting education program, or
an exemption from a parenting education program under Division 3 [Parenting Education Program] of this Part;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: referrals to other resources, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: where and how to seek legal advice,
where and how to access legal information,
where and how to access resources for issues that are not legal in nature, and
where and how to access resources for children dealing with family changes;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assessment of whether consensual dispute resolution under Division 4 [Consensual Dispute Resolution] of this Part is not appropriate;
assessment of any risk of family violence;
referrals to other resources for individuals and families experiencing or concerned about family violence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Needs assessor
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Division, a needs assessor must be a family justice counsellor appointed under section 10 (1) [family justice counsellors] of the Family Law Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Completing parenting education program
bcl:section.bcl:text: Each party must complete a parenting education program unless the needs assessor exempts that party because

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that party has already completed the parenting education program in the 2 years before the date of the needs assessment,
the family law matter is only related to spousal support,
every child involved in the family law matter has reached 19 years of age,
that party cannot access the online version,
the parenting education program is not available in a language in which that party is fluent,
that party cannot complete an online version due to literacy challenges, or
that party cannot complete the parenting education program due to a serious medical condition.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Participating in consensual dispute resolution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The parties must attempt to resolve a family law matter by participating in at least one consensual dispute resolution session unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a needs assessor determines that the parties cannot access consensual dispute resolution services, or
a needs assessor or a consensual dispute resolution professional determines that participation at a consensual dispute resolution session is not appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To prepare for the consensual dispute resolution session, each party must participate in any preparatory meetings or other preparatory process as required by the consensual dispute resolution professional.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Financial information for consensual dispute resolution
bcl:section.bcl:text: If financial information for consensual dispute resolution is required, it must be provided in the form required by the consensual dispute resolution professional.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Part 3 — Application about Family Law Matters
Division 1 — Applying for Family Law Matter Orders

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about family law matters

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, order about a family law matter means an order about any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a new order about a family law matter;
an order to change or cancel all or part of an existing final order about a family law matter;
an order to set aside or replace all or part of a written agreement about a family law matter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To apply for an order about a family law matter in an early resolution registry, a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meet the applicable early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements], and
after having met the early resolution requirements, file and serve on each other party an application about a family law matter in Form C [Application About a Family Law Matter] of Appendix C.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 236/2020, Sch. 1, s. 15.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional requirements when applying for certain orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party must file the following additional documents with an application about a family law matter:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for an order about an existing order or written agreement, a copy of the existing order or written agreement;
for an order about child support, a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C and any information or documents required by the child support guidelines;
for an order about spousal support, a financial statement in Form D of Appendix C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to filing the additional documents under subsection (1), a party applying for an order about being appointed as a guardian must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file the following additional documents with the party's application:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a Consent for Child Protection Record Check in Form 5 under the Family Law Act Regulation;
a request, in the form provided by the registry, to search the protection order registry, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: certify on the application that the party has initiated a criminal record check.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional documents required when applying for orders about guardianship

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party making an application for an order about guardianship under section 51 [orders respecting guardianship] of the Family Law Act, including an application for a consent order for guardianship, must file an affidavit in Form 34 [Affidavit] of Appendix A with the following exhibits attached:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a record check from the Ministry of Children and Family Development;
a child protection order record check from the protection order registry;
a criminal record check.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The documents referred to in subsection (1) must be filed and served on each other party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 7 days before the date set for the court appearance of the application if no trial preparation conference is scheduled, or
at least 7 days before the date of the trial preparation conference if a trial preparation conference is scheduled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following periods apply in relation to the documents referred to in subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an affidavit referred to in subsection (1) must be sworn no more than 7 days before the date the affidavit is filed;
the record checks referred to in subsections (1), (a), (b) and (c) must be dated within 60 days before the date that the record check is filed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Serving application about family law matter

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party is applying for an order about a family law matter under section 15 [applying for orders about family law matters], the party must ensure the personal service of the application about the family law matter by having an adult who is not a party leave a copy of the following documents with the party who is to be served:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application about the family law matter;
instructions, in the form provided by the registry, about the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: how to file a reply;
how to obtain Form F [Reply to an Application About a Family Law Matter (with Counter Application)] of Appendix C for filing a reply;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any applicable additional documents, as described in sections 17 [additional requirements when applying for certain orders] and 17.1 [additional documents required when applying for orders about guardianship].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a certificate of service is required under these rules, an adult who serves documents under subsection (1) must complete a certificate of service in Form E [Certificate of Service] of Appendix C and provide it to the party who filed the application about the family law matter.

If a reply is not filed under Division 2 within 30 days of service of an application about a family law matter under subsection (1), the party applying for an order about a family law matter must file the certificate of service.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Division 2 — Family Law Matter Reply and Counter Application

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: After receipt of application about family law matter

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When a party is served with an application about a family law matter, the party may reply to the application about a family law matter, as described in section 21 [reply to application about family law matter].
If the party served with an application about a family law matter does not reply, the consequences described in section 23 [if no reply filed] apply.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Early resolution requirements must be met before filing reply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before filing a reply to an application about a family law matter under section 21, a party must meet the applicable early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reply to application about family law matter
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a party is served with an application about a family law matter and replies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party must file a completed reply in Form F [Reply to an Application About a Family Law Matter] of Appendix C within 30 days after the date that the party is served the application about the family law matter,
the party may, in the reply, do any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: agree with one or more of the orders applied for in the application about the family law matter;
disagree with one or more of the orders applied for in the application about the family law matter;
make a counter application in accordance with section 22, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the application about the family law matter involves child support or spousal support, the party must file a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for counter application

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In a reply, a party may include a counter application to apply for an order about a different family law matter that was not included in the application about a family law matter.

If the counter application involves an existing agreement or order, child support, spousal support or appointment of a guardian, the party must file any applicable additional documents, as described in section 17 [additional requirements when applying for certain orders].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: If no reply filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a party does not file a reply in accordance with section 21 (a) [reply to application about family law matter],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party is not entitled to receive notice of any part of the proceedings, including any conference, court appearance, hearing or trial, and
a judge may make orders without that party's knowledge.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may direct matters if party does not file reply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 23, a judge may direct that a party who does not file a reply under section 21 [reply to application about family law matter] receive notice of and attend a family management conference or another conference or court appearance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Copy to filing party
bcl:section.bcl:text: After the reply is filed, the registry must, within 21 days, provide a copy of the reply and all documents filed with the reply to the party who filed the family law matter claim.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replying to counter application
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party may reply to a counter application by filing and serving a reply to the counter application in Form G [Reply to a Counter Application] of Appendix C within 30 days after the date that the party receives the reply with counter application.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Family management conferences
bcl:section.bcl:text: A family management conference is an informal and time-limited process in which a judge

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may assist the parties to identify the issues to be resolved,
may explore options to resolve the issues,

may, if needed, make orders and directions under Part 5 [Case Management Orders] based on information provided by or on behalf of the parties to ensure a file is ready to proceed to the next step in the process,

may, if needed, make interim orders under section 36 [interim orders], based on evidence provided by or on behalf of the parties regarding family law matters, to address needs until the parties resolve their family law matters in a subsequent step in the process, and
may, if needed, make orders under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 23 [if no reply filed], if a party does not file a reply,
section 37 [consent orders], by consent of the parties, and
section 41 [orders made in the absence of a party], in the absence of a party.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Family management conference required after compliance with Part 3
bcl:section.bcl:text: All parties to an application about a family law matter must attend a family management conference after complying with Part 3 [Application about Family Law Matters].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Who must attend family management conference

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: All parties must attend the family management conference.
A lawyer of each party may attend the family management conference with the party.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Family management conference may proceed
bcl:section.bcl:text: A family management conference may proceed without a party who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not file a reply, or
does not attend.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information presented in family management conferences
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of a family management conference, the parties may be required to provide the following for consideration by a judge:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: information provided in an application about a family law matter, reply or reply to counter application, if any;
information provided in a financial statement;
evidence given orally on oath or affirmation;
affidavit evidence;
submissions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Intention to proceed — family management conferences

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of intention to proceed with an application about a family law matter must be filed in accordance with subsection (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party has filed an application about a family law matter,
there is no final order in respect of the application, and
more than one year has passed since the parties have taken any step under these rules.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If subsection (1) applies, before the parties may proceed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party must file a notice of intention to proceed in Form B [Notice of Intention to Proceed] of Appendix C, serve it on the other party and file a certificate of service, and
the parties must participate in a family management conference.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Division 2 — Scheduling the Family Management Conference

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scheduling family management conference if reply filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an application about a family law matter and a reply have been filed, the registry must provide the parties with information about the procedure for scheduling the family management conference.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scheduling family management conference if no reply filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an application about a family law matter has been filed and a reply has not been filed and, based on the certificate of service, at least 30 days have passed since the application about a family law matter was served, the registry must provide the party who filed the application about a family law matter with information about the procedure for scheduling the family management conference.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Directions to attend
bcl:section.bcl:text: At a family management conference, a judge may direct a party to do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attend consensual dispute resolution;
attend a family case conference;
return for another family management conference;
attend a trial preparation conference;
attend a hearing or trial.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interim orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: At a family management conference, a judge may make one or more of the following interim orders:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: parental responsibilities;
parenting time;
contact with a child;
child support;
spousal support;
guardianship of a child.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consent orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: At a family management conference, a judge may make one or more of the following orders, including final orders, with consent of the parties:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: parental responsibilities;
parenting time;
contact with a child;
child support;
spousal support;
guardianship of a child.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Completion of early resolution requirements
bcl:section.bcl:text: At a family management conference, a judge may make an order that a party complete the early resolution requirements under section 5 [early resolution requirements].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Conduct orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: At a family management conference, a judge may make any conduct order that may be made under Division 5 of Part 10 [Orders Respecting Conduct] of the Family Law Act, including the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibiting a party from making an application respecting any matter over which a parenting coordinator has authority to act under an agreement or order, other than an application changing or setting aside a parenting coordinator determination, without permission of the judge, under section 223 [orders respecting case management] of the Family Law Act;
requiring the parties to participate in family dispute resolution under section 224 (1) (a) [orders respecting dispute resolution, counselling and programs] of the Family Law Act;
requiring the parties to attend counselling, specified services or programs, under section 224 (1) (b) of the Family Law Act;

allocating or requiring one party to pay the fees related to the family dispute resolution, counselling, specified services or programs, if the party is ordered to attend, under section 224 (2) of the Family Law Act;

setting restrictions or conditions respecting communication between parties, including respecting when or how communications may be made, under section 225 [orders restricting communications] of the Family Law Act, unless it would be more appropriate for a protection order to be made by a judge under Part 9 [Protection from Family Violence] of that Act;
reporting to the court or to a person named by the judge at the time and in the manner specified, under section 227 [other orders respecting conduct] of the Family Law Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Preparing for subsequent hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: The parties may be required to attend a family management conference to prepare for a hearing, even if Part 3 [Application about Family Law Matters] does not apply to the parties, if one of the parties has requested one of the following orders:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reviewing, enforcing, changing or setting aside a determination of a parenting coordinator;
permitting or prohibiting the relocation of a child under section 69 [orders respecting relocation] of the Family Law Act;
setting reasonable and necessarily incurred expenses under any of the following sections of the Family Law Act:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 61 [denial of parenting time or contact];
section 62 [when denial is not wrongful];
section 212 [orders respecting disclosure];
section 213 [enforcing orders respecting disclosure];
section 228 [enforcing orders respecting conduct];
section 230 [enforcing orders generally].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Orders made in the absence of a party

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the family management conference, a judge may make an order, including final orders, in the absence of a party.
A judge may change, suspend or cancel an order made in the absence of a party if the judge determines that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the absent party applied within a reasonable time for the change, suspension or cancellation of the order using Form H [Application for Case Management Order] of Appendix C, and
either of the following apply:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the absent party did not receive notice of the application or family management conference;
there is a good reason to change, suspend or cancel the order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case management orders — general

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A judge may make orders to manage a case, including orders about the following with or without application by a party:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: transferring a court file to another registry for all purposes or specific purposes;
adding or removing a party to a case, including leave to intervene under section 204 (2) of the Family Law Act;
settling or correcting the terms of an order made under these rules;
setting a specified period for the filing and exchanging of information or evidence, including a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C;
correcting or amending a filed document, including the correction of a name or date of birth;
requiring that a parentage test be taken under section 33 [parentage tests] of the Family Law Act;
specifying or requiring information that must be disclosed by a person who is not a party to a case;
adjourning a court appearance;
relating to a report under section 211 [orders respecting reports] of the Family Law Act, including requiring that a person who prepared the report attend a trial as a witness;
respecting the conduct of a party or management of a case, including pre-trial and trial process and evidence disclosure, as set out in rule 8 (4) (a), (b) or (g) of these rules;
respecting the appointment of a lawyer to represent

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the interests of a child, or
a party;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: allowing a person to attend a conference or hearing using electronic communication, including by telephone or video;
waiving or modifying any requirement related to service or giving notice to a person, including allowing an alternative method for the service of a document;

waiving or modifying any other requirement under these rules, including a time limit set under these rules or a time limit set by an order or direction of a judge, even after the time limit has expired;
requiring access to information in accordance with section 242 [orders respecting searchable information] of the Family Law Act;
recognizing an extraprovincial order other than a support order;
relating to the management of a court record, file or document, including access to a court file;
cancelling a subpoena.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may apply for a case management order under subsection (1) by filing and serving the following on any other parties, at least 7 days before the date set for the court appearance:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for a case management order in Form H [Application for Case Management Order];
any supporting evidence or documents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Case management orders — without notice or appearance

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may request in Form I [Application for Case Management Order Without Notice or Attendance] of Appendix C the case management orders described in section 42 (1) (l) to (p) without notice to any other parties or without attending before the court.
The judge reviewing an application under this section for a case management order without notice or attendance may do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: grant the order without the attendance of the parties;
give directions to obtain further information, including to require the parties to attend to speak to the matter;
require that notice be given to any other parties;
reject the application with reasons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a case management order is made without notice under this section, the party who applied for the order must ensure that the other party is served the case management order that is made.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replying to applications for case management orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party is served with an application under this Part and chooses to reply, the party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must attend court on the date and time referred to in the application for the court appearance, and
may file a written response in reply to the application in Form Q [Written Response to Application] of Appendix C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party chooses to file a written response in reply under subsection (1) (b), the party must file and serve the written response on each other party before the date referred to in the application for the court appearance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Priority — protection orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: The application for an order about a protection order may be made before complying with the early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements] if a party is applying for both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order about a protection order;
an order about a family law matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for Family Law Act protection orders or to change or terminate protection orders — with notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is applying for an order about the following must file an application about a protection order in Form K [Application about a Protection Order] of Appendix C and any supporting evidence or documents:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a protection order under section 183 [orders respecting protection] of the Family Law Act;
to change a term or condition of, or to terminate, a protection order under section 187 [changing or terminating orders respecting protection] of the Family Law Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is applying for an order about a protection order under subsection (1), the person must ensure the personal service of the application and supporting evidence or documents by having an adult who is not a party leave a copy of the application and the supporting evidence or documents with the other party at least 7 days before the date referred to in the application for the court appearance.

The adult who serves the application under subsection (2) must complete a certificate of service in Form E [Certificate of Service] of Appendix C and provide it to the person applying for an order about a protection order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for Family Law Act protection orders or to change or terminate protection orders — without notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is applying for an order about the following, without notice, must file an application about a protection order in Form K [Application About a Protection Order] of Appendix C, and any supporting evidence or documents:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a protection order under section 183 [orders respecting protection] of the Family Law Act;
to change a term or condition of, or to terminate, a protection order under section 187 [changing or terminating orders respecting protection] of the Family Law Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is applying for an order about a protection order under subsection (1) must include with the application a statement of the reasons why the application is being made without notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence at protection order hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: Evidence at a protection order hearing under section 45 [applying for Family Law Act protection orders or to change or terminate protection orders — with notice] or 46 [applying for Family Law Act protection orders or to change or terminate protection orders — without notice] may be given

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: orally on oath or affirmation, or
by affidavit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Judge to make new protection order
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a judge changes a term or condition of an existing protection order, including an extension of the protection order, a judge must terminate the existing protection order and make a new protection order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What happens if protection order is made or changed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a judge makes or changes a protection order in accordance with this Division, a clerk must, as soon as possible,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare the protection order, unless the judge directs otherwise,
provide a copy of the protection order to the protection order registry,
arrange service or provide a copy of the protection order on or to the party against whom the protection order was made or changed, as follows:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if that party is present when the order is made or changed, provide the party with the protection order;
if that party is not present when the order is made or changed, arrange for the personal service of the protection order on that party within British Columbia;

if the registry is unable to arrange service under subparagraph (ii) or that party is evading service, notify the person who obtained the order and that person would subsequently be responsible for service, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide a copy of the protection order to the person who applied for the order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What happens if protection order is terminated
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a judge terminates a protection order, a clerk must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare the order terminating a protection order in Form L [Order Terminating a Protection Order] of Appendix C, unless the judge directs otherwise,
provide a copy of the termination order to the protection order registry, and
provide a copy of the termination order to all parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Form of orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: A protection order made under Part 9 [Protection from Family Violence] of the Family Law Act must be in Form 25 [Protection Order] of Appendix A of these rules and does not need to be signed by the parties or their lawyers.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No limitation on protection order applications
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person may make subsequent applications about protection orders, including in the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an earlier application for a protection order was denied or dismissed;
the protection order has expired;
the protection order has been changed or terminated.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Division 2 — Orders about Priority Parenting Matters

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Priority — priority parenting matters
bcl:section.bcl:text: The application for an order about a priority parenting matter may be made before complying with the early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements] if a party is applying for both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order about a priority parenting matter;
an order about a family law matter.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about priority parenting matters
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply to a judge to obtain, or to change a term or condition of or to terminate, an order about a priority parenting matter, a person must file and serve

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application for an order about a priority parenting matter in Form M [Application About Priority Parenting Matter] of Appendix C, and
any supporting evidence or documents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notifying other person about order about priority parenting matter
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply to a judge for an order about a priority parenting matter under this Division, a party must serve any other parties as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the application and supporting documents at least 7 days before the date set for the court appearance unless the application is made without notice or with less than 7 days' notice;
if there is an address for service in the case on the court file for the party to be served,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving the documents at the party's address for service,
by mailing the documents by ordinary mail to the party's address for service,
if a party's address for service includes an email address, by emailing the documents to that email address, or
if a party's address for service includes a fax number, by faxing the documents to that fax number;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if there is no address for service on the court file for the party to be served by arranging for an adult who is not a party to leave the documents with the party to be served, unless otherwise ordered.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Priority parenting matters — without notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may, under section 54, apply to make an application for an order about a priority parenting matter without notice to any party by completing Form I [Application for Case Management Order Without Notice or Attendance] of Appendix C.
If a judge determines that a party should be given notice of an application made under section 54, the judge may make directions regarding

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date for the court appearance,
the amount of notice,
how notice is to be given, and
any other directions that the judge considers appropriate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence presented at hearings for orders about priority parenting matters
bcl:section.bcl:text: Evidence for a hearing with respect to the application for an order about a priority parenting matter may be given

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: orally on oath or affirmation, or
by affidavit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about relocation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party is applying for an order under section 69 [orders respecting relocation] of the Family Law Act prohibiting the relocation of a child, and
a written agreement or order referred to in section 65 [definition and application] of the Family Law Act respecting parenting arrangements or contact with the child applies to the child.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who is applying for an order under section 69 of the Family Law Act prohibiting the relocation of a child must file and serve the following on each other party, at least 7 days before the date referred to in the application for the court appearance:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for an order prohibiting the relocation of a child in Form O [Application for Order Prohibiting the Relocation of a Child] of Appendix C;
a copy of the applicable written agreement or order referred to in section 65 of the Family Law Act;
a copy of, or the details about, the notice of relocation described in section 66 [notice of relocation] of the Family Law Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for consent orders about family law matters without court appearance
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply for an order about a family law matter by consent without a court appearance, the parties must file the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for a consent order in Form N [Application for a Family Law Matter Consent Order] of Appendix C;
a draft consent order in Form 20 [Consent Order] of Appendix A signed by the parties or their lawyers;
any applicable additional documents, as described in

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 17 [additional requirements when applying for certain orders], and
section 17.1 [additional documents required when applying for orders about guardianship], in accordance with that section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consideration of consent order
bcl:section.bcl:text: In considering whether to make a consent order, a judge may do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give directions to obtain further information, including to require the parties to attend to speak to the matter;
amend the draft consent order and require the parties to attend to review and sign the changes;
reject the application with reasons.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Repealed
bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 236/2020, Sch. 1, s. 45.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for consent orders about case management

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The parties applying for a consent order about a case management order must file,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the parties wish to speak to the matter, an application for case management orders in Form H [Application for Case Management Order], or
if the parties do not wish to speak to the matter,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an application for case management orders without an appearance in Form H [Application for Case Management Order] of Appendix C, and
a draft consent order in Form 20 [Consent Order] of Appendix A signed by the parties or their lawyers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The judge considering an application for a consent case management order may do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give directions to obtain further information, including to require the parties to attend to speak to the matter;
amend the draft consent order and require the parties to attend to review and sign the changes;
reject the application with reasons.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General process for consent orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an application is made for a consent order without the parties speaking to the matter, a clerk must place the application, draft consent order and supporting documents before a judge, who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: approve and sign the consent order without the parties having to attend,
require a party to file additional information, or
direct that the parties, and any other person specified by the judge, attend before the judge to explain why the order should be made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the judge gives a direction under subsection (1) (c), a clerk must notify the parties and any other person specified by the judge of the direction, including the date, time and place for the court appearance and any other information in the direction.
If a consent order is made, a clerk must provide a filed copy of the consent order to the parties or their lawyers.
Parties who have applied for a consent order and have had their application rejected must include a copy of the reasons for rejection with subsequent related applications for consent orders.
The parties may apply for a consent order at any time while appearing before a judge by providing evidence as the judge may require.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about enforcement
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party who is applying for an order about any of the following must file and serve on each other party, at least 7 days before the date referred to in the application for the court appearance, an application about enforcement in Form P [Application About Enforcement] of Appendix C, including a copy of the agreement, determination or order to be enforced:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enforcing a filed written agreement or order, including enforcing the written agreement or order through a court order under any of the following sections of the Family Law Act:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 61 [denial of parenting time or contact];
section 63 [failure to exercise parenting time or contact];
section 228 [enforcing orders respecting conduct];
section 230 [enforcing orders generally];
section 231 [extraordinary remedies];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enforcing, changing or setting aside a filed determination of a parenting coordinator;
setting reasonable and necessarily incurred expenses under any of the following sections of the Family Law Act:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 61;
section 63;
section 212 [orders respecting disclosure];
section 213 [enforcing orders respecting disclosure];
section 228;
section 230;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determining whether arrears are owing under a support order or agreement made under the Family Law Act and, if so, the amount of the arrears.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Division 6 — Replying to Applications for Other Orders

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replying to applications for other orders set out in this Part

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party is served with an application under this Part and chooses to reply, the party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must attend court on the date and time referred to in the application for the court appearance, and
may file a written response in reply to the application in Form Q [Written Response to Application] of Appendix C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party chooses to file a written response in reply under subsection (1) (b), the party must file and serve the written response on each other party before the date referred to in the application for the court appearance.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Part 7 — Request for Conference or Hearing

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Requesting conference or hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If any of the following circumstances apply, a party may request that a court appearance be scheduled and must file and serve on each other party a request for scheduling in Form R [Request for Scheduling] of Appendix C:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the matter was adjourned by the court without setting a new date;
the matter was struck from the court list by the court;
a party was referred to a program, professional or resource, or required to attend, participate or complete a requirement, by the court;
a party was required by the court to address a deficiency under these rules;
a review of the terms of the order was provided for in the order;
a party is applying to change, suspend or cancel an interim order under section 216 (3) [court may make interim orders] of the Family Law Act;

a party is applying for an interim order under section 216 or 217 [interim orders before changing, suspending or terminating orders] of the Family Law Act after attendance at a family management conference.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party requesting that a court appearance be scheduled must serve the form under subsection (1) on each other party at least 7 days before the date referred to in the application for the court appearance.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Early Resolution and Case Management Model Forms

reg:content.reg:provisionsnote: [Provisions relevant to the enactment of this regulation: Court Rules Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 80, s. 1.]

change.changenote: Rule 1 (1) and (3) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

subrule.subruletext: The purpose of these rules is to allow people to obtain just, speedy, inexpensive and simple resolution of matters arising under the Family Relations Act and certain matters under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act.

Italicized words in square brackets are not part of these rules, are included editorially for convenience of reference only and are not to be used in interpreting the rules or any provision to which the words refer.

change.changenote: Rule 1 (2) definitions of "family justice councillor", "filed copy" and "regional manager" BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

definition.def: means a family court counsellor under section 3 of the Family Relations Act;
, in relation to a document that is filed with a registry, means a copy of the document that is date stamped with the registry stamp;

, in relation to a registry, means the regional manager of Family Justice Services Division (Corrections Branch), Ministry of Attorney General, who is responsible for the region in which the registry is located;

change.changenote: Rule 1 (2) definitions of "file", "filed agreement", "support" and subrule (4) were added by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.
Rule 1 (2) definition of "regional manager" BEFORE amended by BC Reg 27/2013, effective March 18, 2013.

definition.def: , in relation to a registry, means the regional manager of Family Justice Services Division (Justice Services Branch), Ministry of Attorney General, who is responsible for the region in which the registry is located;
