bcl:definition.bcl:text: regional manager, in relation to a registry, means the regional manager of Family Justice Services Division (Justice Services Branch), Ministry of Justice, who is responsible for the region in which the registry is located;

change.changenote: Rule 1 (2) definition of "family justice registry" BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: family justice registry means the Kelowna, Nanaimo, Surrey or Vancouver (Robson Square) registry;

change.changenote: Rule 2 heading BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

rule.ruletext:
Making and Filing an Application
(for Specified Family Relations Act Orders)

change.changenote: Rule 2 (1), (2), (3) and (5) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

subrule.marginalnote: Applying to the court for an order
subrule.subruletext: To apply to the court for any of the following orders under the Family Relations Act, a person must complete an application in Form 1 and file it, together with 3 copies of it, in a registry:

paragraph.paragraphtext: child custody, access or guardianship;
child, spousal or parental maintenance;
a restraining order under section 37 of the Act or an order prohibiting interference with a child under section 38 of that Act.

subrule.marginalnote: Applying to change or cancel an existing order
subrule.subruletext: To apply to the court for any of the following orders, a person must complete an application in Form 2 and file it, together with 3 copies of it, in the registry where the order or agreement is filed unless a judge permits otherwise under rule 19 (1) or rule 19 (5) or (6) applies:

paragraph.paragraphtext: to change or cancel an order that was made or registered under the Family Relations Act;
to cancel or reduce arrears under a maintenance order that was made or registered under the Family Relations Act;
to change or cancel an agreement that was filed under the Family Relations Act.

indent1.em: [To file the application in another registry, see rule 19 concerning transfer of court files. Rule 19 (5) and (6) specifically concern transfer of files by the registry when the parties consent to the transfer or when only one of the parties resides in British Columbia and that party requests the transfer.]

subrule.marginalnote: Personal service of application, not by the applicant
subrule.subruletext: Unless a judge grants permission to use a different method of service under rule 9 (7), an applicant under subrule (1) or (2) must have a filed copy of the application served personally on the respondent by a person, other than the applicant, who is at least 19 years of age.
If the respondent does not file a reply to the application in accordance with rule 3, the applicant must file with the registry an affidavit of personal service in Form 5.

indent1.em: [To apply for enforcement of a custody order or for recognition of a custody order or an access order, see rule 16. To apply for enforcement of a maintenance order under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act, see rule 17. To make any other type of application, see rule 12.]

change.changenote: Rule 2 (4) (a) to (c) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

paragraph.paragraphtext: a blank reply form (Form 3);
a blank financial statement form (Form 4), if the applicant seeks an order for child, spousal or parental maintenance or for variation of child, spousal or parental maintenance;
a filed copy of the applicant's financial statement and applicable documentation under rule 4 (2), if applicable.

change.changenote: Rule 2 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 40/2013, effective March 18, 2013.

indent1.em: [To file the application in another registry, see rule 19 concerning transfer of court files. Rule 19 (5) and (6) specifically concerns transfer of files by the registry when the parties consent to the transfer or when only one of the parties resides in British Columbia and that party requests the transfer. If a person seeks an order or direction from a judge in relation to another order, an agreement or the determination of a parenting coordinator, see rule 12 (5).]

change.changenote: Rule 2 (2) (c.1) was added by BC Reg 122/2014, effective June 23, 2014.
Rule 3 heading BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.
Rule 3 (1), (2), (4) and (5) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

subrule.subruletext: A person named as a respondent in an application referred to in rule 2 must, within 30 days after being served with a copy of the application,

paragraph.paragraphtext: complete a reply in Form 3, following the instructions on the form, and
file that reply, together with 3 copies of it, in the registry where the application was filed, and
if applicable, file with that reply the original and 3 copies of the respondent's financial statement and applicable documentation referred to in rule 4 (2) (b).

subrule.subruletext: The respondent may do one or more of the following in the reply:

paragraph.paragraphtext: consent to one or more of the orders requested in the application;
disagree with anything claimed in the application, stating the reasons for the disagreement;
apply to the court for any of the following orders under the Family Relations Act:

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: a restraining order under section 37 of the Act or an order prohibiting interference with a child under section 38 of that Act;

paragraph.paragraphtext: apply to the court for an order

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: to change or cancel an order that was made or registered under the Family Relations Act,
to cancel or reduce arrears under a maintenance order that was made or registered under that Act, or
to change or cancel an agreement that was filed under that Act.

indent1.em: [To apply for enforcement of a custody order or for recognition of a custody order or an access order, see rule 16. To apply for enforcement of a maintenance order under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act, see rule 17. To make any other type of application, see rule 12.]

subrule.marginalnote: How a reply is served on the applicant
subrule.subruletext: Within 21 days after a reply is filed in a registry, the clerk must serve on the applicant a filed copy of the reply and any documents filed by the respondent under subrule (1) (c).

subrule.marginalnote: Applicant needs to respond if the reply includes a counterclaim
subrule.subruletext: If the reply includes a counterclaim under subrule (2) (c) or (d), the applicant must, within 30 days after being served with a copy of the reply,

paragraph.paragraphtext: complete a reply in Form 3, following the instructions on the form,
file that reply, together with 3 copies of it, in the registry where the application under rule 2 was filed, and

serve on the respondent a filed copy of that reply and, if applicable and only if the applicant has not already done so, serve with that reply a filed copy of the applicant's financial statement and applicable documentation referred to in rule 4 (2) (b).

change.changenote: Rule 3 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 40/2013, effective March 18, 2013.

indent1.em: [To apply for enforcement of an order or filed agreement for guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact with a child, see rule 12, or for recognition of an extraprovincial order, see rule 16. To apply for enforcement of a support order under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act, see rule 17.]

change.changenote: Rule 4 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

subrule.marginalnote: Persons who must provide financial information
subrule.subruletext: Subrule (2) applies to the following persons:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a person who applies, in Form 1 or 3, for a spousal or parental maintenance order or who is responding to such an application;
a person who applies, in Form 2 or 3, for variation of a spousal or parental maintenance order or who is responding to such an application;
a person who applies, in Form 1 or 3, for a child maintenance order and who is required under the Child Support Guidelines Regulation to provide income information;
a person who is responding to an application for a child maintenance order;
a person who applies, in Form 2 or 3, for variation of a child maintenance order and who is required under the Child Support Guidelines Regulation to provide income information;
a person who is responding to an application for variation of a child maintenance order and who is required under the Child Support Guidelines Regulation to provide income information;
a person who applies, in Form 2 or 3, for cancellation or reduction of arrears under a maintenance order.

change.changenote: Rule 4 (2) (b) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

paragraph.paragraphtext: when filing the application or the reply, as the case may be, file with the registry the original and 3 copies of that financial statement and any applicable documentation described in Form 4 or required under the Child Support Guidelines Regulation.

change.changenote: Rule 4 (3) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective March 18, 2013.

subrule.marginalnote: If the parties agree on income and amount of child maintenance
subrule.subruletext: Parties to an application for child maintenance or for variation of child maintenance are deemed to have complied with the documentation requirements of the Child Support Guidelines Regulation and the requirement to complete and file financial statements under subrule (2) in respect of that application if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the parties have agreed on the amount of child maintenance to be paid and on the annual income of each party who would otherwise be required to provide income information under that regulation,
the parties have signed a consent in Form 19 respecting that agreement, and

the consent, together with a copy of the most recent income tax return of each party who would otherwise be required to provide income information under that regulation and a copy of that person's most recent income tax notice of assessment or reassessment, have been filed in the registry.

subrule.subruletext: A person representing the government, a ministry or public officer, if they are parties in the matter, need not but may meet with and attend with a family justice counsellor or persons or programs under subrules (3), (4) and (7) (b).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The Early Resolution and Case Management Model does not apply to matters in a court file if

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant under subrule (10) (g) remains in force until

subrule.subruletext: Subject to the exceptions set out in subrule (2), documents may be served by delivering the documents as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: on a party, other than the Director of Maintenance Enforcement,

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: by leaving the documents with the party's lawyer or having a person who is at least 19 years of age, other than the serving party, leave the documents with the party to be served,
by mailing the documents to the last address for service provided by that party under subrule (4) or (5), or
if the address for service provided by that party includes a fax number, by transmitting the documents to that fax number together with a fax cover-page in Form 10;

paragraph.paragraphtext: on the Director of Maintenance Enforcement, by mailing the documents to the post office box number provided by the director;
on any other person, by leaving the documents with the person or by mailing the documents by double registered mail to that person's postal address.

subrule.subruletext: Subrule (1) does not apply in the case of a summons, a subpoena, an application in Form 1, 2, 21 or 22 or a request in Form 23.

indent1.em: [Forms 1 and 2 concern applications for custody, access, guardianship, maintenance, restraining orders, orders prohibiting interference with a child and applications to change or cancel existing orders or agreements filed under the Family Relations Act. These forms must be served personally on the respondent (see rule 2 (3) to (5)).]

[Form 21 concerns applications to authorize peace officer enforcement of existing custody orders under section 36 of the Family Relations Act. These applications are brought without notice to other persons.]

[Form 22 concerns applications to recognize custody and access orders made by courts outside of British Columbia and these application forms must be served personally on the respondents (see rule 16 (4)).]

[Form 23 is related to enforcing existing maintenance orders and is a request to the court for issuance of a summons, warrant or garnishing order. These applications are generally made without notice to the person against whom the summons or warrant will be issued or against whom the order will be made.]

subrule.subruletext: Unless a judge grants permission to use a different method of service under subrule (7), a summons (Form 7) issued under rule 6 (4) (e) or (10) (f) must be served on the respondent at least 3 days before the date of the hearing referred to in the summons as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a clerk may have it served on the respondent by mail or fax or personally by a peace officer or any adult other than the applicant;
the applicant may have it served on the respondent personally by any adult other than the applicant.

subrule.subruletext: Each time a party files a document with the registry, the party must provide in the document the party's current address for service.

subrule.marginalnote: Party must notify of change of address
subrule.subruletext: If a party's address for service changes, the party must promptly file with the registry a notice of change of address in Form 11 and serve a copy of the notice on the other parties.

If an affidavit or certificate referred to in the following paragraphs is completed in accordance with the instructions on the applicable form and is filed in the registry, the affidavit or certificate is proof of service of the document to which the affidavit or certificate relates:

paragraph.paragraphtext: in relation to a document served by mail or fax, an affidavit of service in Form 13;
in relation to a document served personally by an individual other than a peace officer, an affidavit of personal service in Form 5;
in relation to a document served personally by a peace officer, a certificate of service in Form 14.

subrule.subruletext: In this rule, paternity tests include human leukocyte antigen tissue tests and tests of the deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) in tissue or blood to identify the inheritable characteristics of the tissue or blood.

subrule.marginalnote: Judge may order samples to be taken for paternity test
subrule.subruletext: If the parentage of a child is denied in a proceeding for a maintenance order for the child, a judge may order putative parents and the child to have tissue or blood samples, or both, taken by a medical practitioner or other qualified person so that paternity tests can be done on the samples.
An order under subrule (2) may include any terms or conditions the judge thinks proper and may require a putative parent to pay all or part of the cost of the paternity tests.
The results of paternity tests done under subrule (2) may be introduced as evidence.
If a putative parent named in an order under subrule (2) fails to comply with the order, the judge may draw any inference from that failure that the judge considers appropriate.
An application for an order under subrule (2) must be brought by notice of motion under rule 12.

subrule.subruletext: To apply to the court under section 36 of the Family Relations Act for an order authorizing a peace officer to apprehend a child for the purposes of enforcing a custody order, a person must complete an application in Form 21 and file it in a registry, together with a certified copy of the custody order as proof of the order.

subrule.subruletext: To apply to the court under section 48 of the Family Relations Act for an order recognizing a custody or access order made by an extraprovincial tribunal, a person must complete an application in Form 22 and file it in a registry, together with 3 copies of it and a certified copy of the custody or access order as proof of the order.

subrule.marginalnote: Judge may order transfer of files
subrule.subruletext: On application by notice of motion to a judge under rule 12, the judge may order that a file be transferred to another registry.

The transfer application must be made in the registry where the file is located or, if the application relates to an order or agreement referred to in rule 2 (2), the applicant must apply to a judge at the registry where the order or agreement is filed.
Before granting permission to transfer a file to another registry or to file an application at another registry, the judge must consider

paragraph.paragraphtext: the balance of convenience, and
any special circumstances that exist.

subrule.subruletext: A clerk may transfer a file to another registry for the purposes of all or any part of the proceedings, if the parties

paragraph.paragraphtext: complete a consent to the transfer in Form 27, and
file the consent in the registry where the file is located.

subrule.marginalnote: Transfer of file without order or consent
subrule.subruletext: A clerk may transfer a file to another registry, for the purposes of one application or for all purposes, if

paragraph.paragraphtext: only one of the parties, other than the Director of Maintenance Enforcement, resides in British Columbia, and
the party residing in British Columbia files with the registry a written request for the transfer.

change.changenote: Rule 20 (4), (9), (10) and (12) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 132/2012, effective December 13, 2013.

subrule.marginalnote: Changing or cancelling orders made in the absence of a party
subrule.subruletext: A judge may change or cancel an order made in the absence of a person, or made when the person failed to file a reply, if

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is a good reason for changing or cancelling the order, and
that person applies by notice of motion to a judge under rule 12 within a reasonable time and attaches to the application an affidavit containing

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: the reason the person did not file a reply or attend before the court when required,
the reason for any delay if there has been delay in filing the application, and
the facts that support the application.

subrule.subruletext: A person must not disclose any information contained in a record filed under rule 4 [financial information] except to the extent necessary for the purposes of an application under the Family Relations Act.

No one is entitled to search a registry file respecting an application under the Family Relations Act, an agreement filed under section 121 of that Act or an application under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act except

paragraph.paragraphtext: a party,
a party's lawyer,
a person who is named in the application as a respondent or who is named as a party to the agreement, as the case may be,
a family justice counsellor, or
a person authorized by a judge.

subrule.subruletext: A copy of a written agreement referred to in section 121 (2) of the Family Relations Act may be filed in a registry and, if the agreement was made before July 1, 1995, a consent of the parties, in Form 28, must be filed with the agreement.

subrule.subruletext: The purpose of this rule is to promote the best interests of children by providing a program of information, the Parenting after Separation Program, to persons in dispute over issues respecting children.

subrule.marginalnote: Parties in some cases need not attend
subrule.subruletext: None of the parties need attend the program if one of the parties files a request for the purpose of exemption in Form 31 and

subrule.marginalnote: A party who has already attended
subrule.subruletext: A party need not attend the program if that party files a request for the purpose of exemption in Form 31 correctly stating that the party has attended and completed the program in the 24 months immediately preceding the date of filing the declaration.

subrule.marginalnote: A party who is unable to attend the program
subrule.subruletext: A party is exempt from this rule if the party provides to the program administrator a request for the purpose of exemption in Form 31 that correctly states one of the following reasons:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the party is not fluent in a language in which the program is offered;
the party resides in a community where the program is not offered;
the party is incapable of attending due to a serious medical condition.

subrule.marginalnote: Both parties must attend program before court appearance
subrule.subruletext: If this rule applies, but subject to subrules (4), (5), (6) and (7), both the applicant and respondent must attend the program and must file in the registry a Certificate of Attendance on or before the date of the first court appearance.

form.centertext: In the Provincial Court of British Columbia

lefttext.strong:
IMPORTANT NOTE TO RESPONDENT:
If this application contains a claim for maintenance, you are required to file financial information with your reply. If you do not, the court may attribute income to you and set the amount of maintenance to be paid. The applicant has estimated your gross annual income as set out in item

form.indent1: [ ] custody [ ] guardianship [ ] access
[ ] maintenance for a child [ ] spousal maintenance [ ] parental maintenance
[ ] an order prohibiting the respondent from interfering with the child(ren) and/or ................................[name]...........................
[ ] an order restraining the respondent from harassing the child(ren) and/or ................................[name]...........................
form.lefttext: Are there any court orders or written agreements between the parties concerning separation, custody, access or maintenance?
form.indent1:
[ ] No orders [ ] I am attaching copies of all other orders
[ ] No written agreements [ ] I am attaching copies of all other written agreements
form.lefttext: 2 — Children (complete if you are asking for custody, access, or child maintenance or a restraining order)
The respondent's relationship to the child(ren) is .........................................................
3 — Maintenance (complete if you are asking for child or spousal maintenance)
I am asking for: (complete only if you are asking for child maintenance)
form.indent1: [ ] maintenance in the amount set out in the Child Support Table for ..........[number]......... children
form.lefttext: If this application contains a claim for maintenance, you must complete Form 4, following the instructions on that form, if:
• there is a claim for spousal or parental maintenance, or
• there is a claim for child maintenance and one or more of the following applies:
form.indent1: • you are the person being asked to pay;
• the claim is for an amount other than the amount set out in the tables of the Child Support Guidelines;
• there is a claim of undue hardship;
• there is a claim for special or extraordinary expenses;
• the parents have split custody (that is, there are 2 or more children and each parent has sole custody of at least one child);
• the parents have shared custody (that is, each parent exercises access to or has physical custody of a child for not less than 40% of the time over the course of a year);
• one or more of the children for whom maintenance is claimed is of the age of majority (19 years in B.C.) or older;
• the person who is being asked to pay is not a biological or adoptive parent of the child but has acted as a parent to one or more of the children for whom maintenance is claimed.
form.lefttext: You may also provide this financial information before receiving the respondent's reply, in order to avoid delay, if you believe that the income of a respondent from whom child maintenance is claimed is over $150 000 per year or that the respondent will claim undue hardship, special or extraordinary expenses or make a counterclaim for maintenance.
4 — Restraining Orders (complete if you are asking for a restraining order)

I am asking for an order prohibiting the respondent from interfering with or harassing the child(ren) and/or myself because .............................................................................................................................................

Note to respondent: If you fail to file a reply within 30 days of being served with this application you will not receive notice of any part of the proceeding and the court may make an order against you.

indent1.strong: This form must be used when transmitting documents to the court registry by fax for filing.

form.lefttext: This is a pilot project, not available at all Court locations, and is subject to limitations set out in Court Rules, Practice Directives and at the Court Services website at www.ag.gov.bc.ca/courts/fax/fax.htm.

It is the responsibility of the person transmitting a document to ensure that the document is filed in the registry within the required filing time. The registry takes no responsibility for difficulty experienced when transmitting a document by fax to the registry. The registry cannot guarantee that any document will be filed on the day it is received in the registry.

Documents transmitted to the registry will be processed in the order they are received. Confirmation of acceptance or refusal will be forwarded as soon as possible to you at the return fax number set out below or by mail if indicated.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Division 1 — Making Family Law Matter Claims

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 15 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Early resolution requirements must be met before filing claim
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before filing a claim about a family law matter, a party must meet the applicable early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements].

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 16 BEFORE repealed by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for family law matter claim

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who is seeking an order about the following must file and serve a family law matter claim in Form C [Family Law Matter Claim] of Appendix C:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a new order about a family law matter;
to change or cancel all or part of an existing order or filed written agreement about a family law matter;
to set aside or replace all or part of a written agreement about a family law matter that has not been filed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The family law matter claim under subsection (1) must be accompanied by the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C;
an affidavit;
any supporting evidence or documents.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 17 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional documents when applying for certain orders
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the party is applying for one of the following orders, the family law matter claim must be filed with the following appropriate additional documents for the order:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in relation to an existing order or written agreement, a copy of the existing order or written agreement;

in relation to child support, if the child support guidelines require the person to provide information, a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C and any other documents required by the child support guidelines;
in relation to spousal support, a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C;
to be appointed as a guardian of a child, an affidavit in Form 34 [Affidavit] of Appendix A with the following exhibits attached:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a record check from the Ministry of Children and Family Development;
a protection order record check from the protection order registry;
a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 17.1 was enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.
Appendix B, section 18 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Serving family law matter claim

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party making a family law matter claim under section 16 must arrange for the service of the family law matter claim by arranging for an adult who is not a party to leave a copy of the following documents with the party to be served:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family law matter claim;
a blank copy of Form F [Reply to a Family Law Matter Claim] of Appendix C;
any applicable additional documents, as described in section 17.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The adult who serves documents under subsection (1) is to complete a certificate of service in Form E [Certificate of Service] of Appendix C and provide it to the party making the family law matter claim.
If a reply is not filed under Division 2 within 21 days, the party making the family law matter claim must file the Certificate of Service.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: After receipt of family law matter claim

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: When a party is served with a family law matter claim, the party may reply to the family law matter claim, as described in section 21 [replying to family law matter claim].
If the party served with a family law matter claim does not reply, the consequences described in section 23 [if no reply filed] apply.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 20 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Early resolution requirements must be met before filing reply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before filing a reply to a family law matter claim under section 21, a party must meet the applicable early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements].

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 21 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replying to family law matter claim
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a party is served with a family law matter claim and replies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party must file a completed reply in Form F [Reply to a Family Law Matter Claim] of Appendix C within 21 days after the date that the party is served the family law matter claim,
the party may, in the reply, do any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: agree with one or more of the orders applied for in a family law matter claim;
disagree with one or more of the orders applied for in a family law matter claim;
make a counterclaim in accordance with section 22, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the family law matter claim involves child support or spousal support, the party must file a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 22 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the counterclaim involves child support or spousal support, the party must file any applicable additional documents, as described in section 17 [additional documents when applying for certain orders].

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 22 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for counterclaim

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the reply, a party may include a counterclaim to apply for an order about a different family law matter that was not included in the family law matter claim.

If the counterclaim involves child support, spousal support or appointment of a guardian, the party must file any applicable additional documents, as described in section 17 [additional documents when applying for certain orders].

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 24 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may direct matters if party does not file reply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 23, a judge may direct that a party who does not file a reply under section 21 [replying to family law matter claim] receive notice of and attend a family management conference or another conference or hearing.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 26 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Replying to counterclaim
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party may reply to a counterclaim by filing and serving a reply to the counterclaim in Form G [Reply to a Counterclaim] of Appendix C within 14 days after the date that the party receives the counterclaim in the reply.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 28 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Family management conference required after compliance with Part 3
bcl:section.bcl:text: All parties to a family law matter claim must attend a family management conference after complying with Part 3 [Applying for Orders about Family Law Matters].

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 31 (a) and (e) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: information provided in a family law matter claim, reply and reply to counterclaim, if any;
submissions offered by the parties or by the lawyers of the parties.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 32 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of intention to proceed must be filed in accordance with subsection (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party has filed a family law matter claim,
there is no final order in respect of the claim, and
more than one year has passed since the parties have taken any action under these rules.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 33 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scheduling family management conference if reply filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a family law matter claim and a reply have been filed, the registry must provide the parties with information about the procedure for scheduling the family management conference.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 34 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Scheduling family management conference if no reply filed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a family law matter claim has been filed and a reply has not been filed and, based on the certificate of service, at least 21 days have passed since the family law matter claim was served, the registry must provide the party who filed the family law matter claim with information about the procedure for scheduling the family management conference.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 36 (a) and (b) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an allocation of parental responsibilities;
an allocation of parenting time;

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 37 (a) and (b) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an allocation of parental responsibilities;
an allocation of parenting time;

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 41 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A judge may change, suspend or cancel an order made in the absence of a party, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is a good reason for changing, suspending or cancelling the order, and
that party applies within a reasonable time for the change, suspension or cancellation of the order using Form H [Application for Case Management Order] of Appendix C.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 42 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: One or more of the following case management orders may be made with or without application by a party:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: transferring the court file to another registry for one or more purposes;
adding or removing a party to the proceeding;
settling or correcting the terms of an order made under these rules;
setting a specified period of time for the filing and exchanging of information, including a financial statement in Form D [Financial Statement] of Appendix C;
correcting or amending a filed document, including the correction of a name or date of birth;
requiring that a parentage test be taken under section 33 [parentage tests] of the Family Law Act;
requiring that information be disclosed by a third party;
adjourning a hearing or trial;
requiring that a person who prepared a report under section 211 [orders respecting reports] of the Family Law Act attend a trial;
respecting the conduct and management of a trial;
allowing a person to attend a hearing or conference using electronic communication;
shortening or extending a time limit set under these rules or a time limit set by an order or direction of a judge;
allowing, waiving or modifying any service, delivery or notice requirement, including allowing an alternate method for the service of a document;
requiring access to information in accordance with section 242 [orders respecting searchable information] of the Family Law Act;
permitting any other means of proof instead of that required by these rules;
waiving or varying any early resolution requirements;
recognizing an extraprovincial order other than a support order;
permitting a party to be exempt from a requirement under these rules.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 42 (1) (d) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: setting a specified period for the filing and exchanging of information or evidence, including a financial statement in Form 4 [Financial Statement];

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 42 (2) (part) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may apply for a case management order under subsection (1) by filing and serving the following on any other parties, at least 7 days before the date set for the hearing:

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 43 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may request in Form I [Application for Case Management Order Without Notice or Appearance] of Appendix C the case management orders described in section 42 (1) (k) to (r) without an appearance or without notice to any other parties.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 43 (1) and (2) (part) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may request in Form I [Application for Case Management Order Without Notice or Appearance] of Appendix C the case management orders described in section 42 (1) (l) to (p) without an appearance or without notice to any other parties.
The judge reviewing an application under this section for a case management order without notice or an appearance may do the following:

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 43.1 was enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.
Appendix B, section 45 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for Family Law Act protection orders or to change or terminate protection orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To apply to a judge to obtain, or to change a term or condition of or to terminate, a protection order under Part 9 [Protection from Family Violence] of the Family Law Act, a person must file

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application about a protection order in Form K [Application about a Protection Order] of Appendix C, and
any supporting evidence or documents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person applying for an order about a protection order under this Division must arrange for the service of the application and supporting documents at least 7 days before the date set for the hearing by arranging for an adult who is not a party to leave a copy of the application and the supporting documents with the party to be served, unless the application is made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: without notice, or
with less than 7 days' notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The adult who serves documents under subsection (2) is to complete a certificate of service in Form E [Certificate of Service] of Appendix C and provide it to the person applying for an order about a protection order.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 46 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection orders — without notice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may, under section 45, apply to make the following application without notice to any party by completing Form I [Application for Case Management Order Without Notice or Appearance] of Appendix C:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a protection order under section 183 [orders respecting protection] of the Family Law Act;
to change a term or condition of or to terminate a protection order under section 187 [changing or terminating orders respecting protection] of the Family Law Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a judge determines that a party should be given notice of an application made under subsection (1), the judge may make directions regarding

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date for the hearing,
the amount of notice,
how notice is to be given, and
any other directions that the judge considers appropriate.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 47 (part) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence at protection order hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: Evidence at a protection order hearing under section 46 may be given

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 48 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Judge to make new protection order
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a judge changes an existing protection order, including an extension of the protection order, a judge must terminate the existing protection order and make a new protection order.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 49 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What happens if protection order is made or changed
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a judge makes or changes a protection order in accordance with this Division, a clerk must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare the protection order unless the judge indicates otherwise,
provide a copy of the protection order to the protection order registry,
serve or provide a copy of the protection order on the party against whom the protection order was made or changed, as follows:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if that party is present when the order is made or changed, provide the party with the protection order;
if that party is not present when the order is made or changed, arrange for the service of the protection order on that party within British Columbia;
if the registry is unable to arrange service under subparagraph (ii), notify the person who obtained the order and that person would subsequently be responsible for service, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide a copy of the protection order to the person who made the application.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 50 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What happens if protection order is terminated
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a judge terminates a protection order, a clerk must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare the termination order in Form L [Order Terminating a Protection Order] of Appendix C,
advise the protection order registry about the termination of the protection order, and
provide a copy of the termination order to all parties.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 52 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No limitation on protection order applications
bcl:section.bcl:text: The expiry of a protection order or the change or termination of a protection order does not prevent a person from applying for subsequent protection orders.

change.changenote: Appendix B, Part 6, Division 2 heading BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Division 2 — Orders about Extraordinary Parenting Matters

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 53 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Priority — extraordinary parenting matters
bcl:section.bcl:text: The application for an order about an extraordinary parenting matter may be made before complying with the early resolution requirements described in section 5 [early resolution requirements] if a party is applying for both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order about an extraordinary parenting matter;
an order about a family law matter.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 54 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about extraordinary parenting matters
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply to a judge to obtain, or to change a term or condition of or to terminate, an order about an extraordinary parenting matter, a person must file and serve

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application for an order about an extraordinary parenting matter in Form M [Application about Extraordinary Parenting Matter] of Appendix C, and
any supporting evidence or documents.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 55 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notifying other person about order about extraordinary parenting matter
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply to a judge for an order about an extraordinary parenting matter under this Division, a party must serve any other parties as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the application and supporting documents at least 7 days before the date set for the court appearance unless the application is made without notice or with less than 7 days’ notice;
if there is an address for service in the case on the court file for the party to be served,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving the documents at the party’s address for service,
by mailing the documents by ordinary mail to the party’s address for service,
if a party’s address for service includes an email address, by emailing the documents to that email address, or
if a party’s address for service includes a fax number, by faxing the documents to that fax number;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if there is no address for service on the court file for the party to be served by arranging for an adult who is not a party to leave the documents with the party to be served, unless otherwise ordered.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 56 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may, under section 54, apply to make an application for an order about an extraordinary parenting matter without notice to any party by completing Form I [Application for Case Management Order Without Notice or Appearance] of Appendix C.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 56 (2) (a) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date for the hearing,

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 57 (part) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Evidence presented at hearings for orders about extraordinary parenting matters
bcl:section.bcl:text: Evidence for a hearing with respect to the application for an order about an extraordinary parenting matter may be given

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 58 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about relocation
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply for an order, under section 69 [orders respecting relocation] of the Family Law Act, prohibiting the relocation of a child, a person must file and serve

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for an order prohibiting the relocation of a child in Form O [Application for Order Prohibiting the Relocation of Child] of Appendix C, and
a copy of the existing order or agreement and the notice of relocation described in section 66 [notice of relocation] of the Family Law Act.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 59 (part) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for consent orders about family law matters without hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply for an order about a family law matter by consent without a hearing, the parties must file the following:

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 59 (c) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any applicable additional documents, as described in section 17 [additional documents when applying for certain orders] of this Early Resolution and Case Management Model.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 61 BEFORE repealed by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consent orders about guardianship
bcl:section.bcl:text: In addition to the material filed under section 59 [applying for consent orders about family law matters without hearing], a party who is applying for appointment as guardian of a child must also file an affidavit in Form 34 [Affidavit] of Appendix A with the following exhibits attached:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of a record check from the Ministry of Children and Family Development;
a protection order record check from the protection order registry;
a criminal record check.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 62 BEFORE repealed by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Administrative matters for consent orders about guardianship
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following time periods apply to applications for consent orders under this Division:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an affidavit under section 17 [additional documents when applying for certain orders] must be sworn no more than 7 days before the date that the material under that section is filed;
the record checks described under section 61 must be dated within 60 days before the date that the material under section 59 is filed.

change.changenote: Appendix B, section 65 BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for orders about enforcement
bcl:section.bcl:text: To apply for an order about enforcement of any of the following, a party must, at least 7 days before the date set for the hearing, file and serve an application for enforcement in Form P [Application for Enforcement] of Appendix C, including a copy of the agreement, determination, or order to be enforced:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enforcing a written agreement or order, including enforcement under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act;
reviewing, enforcing, changing or setting aside a determination of a parenting coordinator;
setting reasonable and necessarily incurred expenses under any of the following sections of the Family Law Act:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 61 [denial of parenting time or contact];
section 212 [orders respecting disclosure];
section 213 [enforcing orders respecting disclosure];
section 228 [enforcing orders respecting conduct];
section 230 [enforcing orders generally];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of extraordinary remedies under section 231 [extraordinary remedies] of the Family Law Act;
determining whether or not arrears are owing under a support order made under the Family Law Act.

change.changenote: Appendix B, Division 6, section 66 was enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.
Appendix B, Part 7, section 67 was enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.
Appendix C was enacted by BC Reg 61/2019, effective May 13, 2019.
Appendix C BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 236/2020, effective December 7, 2020.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Early Resolution and Case Management Model Forms

change.changenote: Appendix C, form H BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.
Appendix C, form I BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.
Appendix C, form M BEFORE re-enacted by BC Reg 119/2020, effective June 1, 2020.
Transitional Provisions BEFORE repealed by BC Reg 120/2020, effective May 17, 2021.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — amendment by this regulation to 21 day timeline
bcl:section.bcl:text: If, in respect of a matter under the Provincial Court (Family) Rules, the 21 day period referred to in section 18 (3), 21 (a) or 34 of Appendix B of the Provincial Court (Family) Rules, as that section read immediately before being amended by this regulation, ends on or after December 7, 2020, the 30 day period referred to in that section, as amended by this regulation, applies to the matter instead.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — amendment by this regulation to 14 day timeline
bcl:section.bcl:text: If, in respect of a matter under the Provincial Court (Family) Rules, the 14 day period referred to in section 26 of Appendix B of the Provincial Court (Family) Rules, as that section read immediately before being amended by this regulation, ends on or after December 7, 2020, the 30 day period referred to in that section, as amended by this regulation, applies to the matter instead.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — family justice registry requirements continue to apply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite the amendment made by section 1 of Schedule 1 of this regulation to the definition of family justice registry in rule 1 (2) of the Provincial Court (Family) Rules, if rule 5 of the Provincial Court (Family) Rules applied to an application in the Surrey registry before December 7, 2020, that rule continues to apply to the application.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transition — designated registry requirements continue to apply
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite the amendment made by section 6 of Schedule 1 of this regulation to the definition of designated registry in rule 21 (1) of the Provincial Court (Family) Rules, if rule 21 of the Provincial Court (Family) Rules applied to an application in the Surrey registry before December 7, 2020, that rule continues to apply to the application.
